Their freedom can‚Äôt wait any longer.

Read our letters: https://www.menendez.senate.gov/news-and-events/press/bipartisan-group-of-senators-call-on-central-asian-leaders-to-release-unjustly-detained-prisoners-at-high-risk-of-covid-19

These 10 people have been unjustly detained for too long. Amid #COVID19, releasing them is an even more urgent issue. That‚Äôs why I, along with 11 of my Senate colleagues, sent letters to the Central Asian presidents urging them to release those detained for peaceful activism NOW.

Akrom Malikov, a researcher at a university in Uzbekistan, was detained on extremism charges for allegedly writing articles for the opposition People‚Äôs Movement. He was convicted of plotting to overthrow the government. @HRW describes the charges as ‚Äúpolitically-motivated.‚Äù http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_zumXsAYU0ft.jpg

Iskandar Khudaiberganov has been serving a life sentence since 2002 for ‚Äúterrorism,‚Äù ‚Äúmurder,‚Äù & ‚Äúattempting to overthrow the constitutional order.‚Äù @HRW says his conviction was based on confessions obtained under torture and witness statements later retracted in court. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_vc5XQAA7mTT.jpg

Omruzak Omarkulyev was arrested after creating an informal Turkmenistan students‚Äô club while studying abroad in Turkey. He‚Äôs reportedly been sentenced to 20 yrs in prison on unknown charges. @freedomnoworg criticized the ‚Äúlack of transparency & political motivation‚Äù in his case. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_p_BXkAACS_O.jpg

Mansur Mingelov was arrested after documenting cases of torture & ill-treatment of the Baloch community in Turkmenistan. @amnesty wrote he was sentenced ‚Äúin an unfair trial in retaliation for complaints about torture in police detention.‚Äù He is at high-risk for #COVID19. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_lZpWAAAZZMO.jpg

Gulgeldy Annaniyazov has been detained in Turkmenistan since 2008, when he returned after living in Norway as a political refugee. He served 11 years for illegal entry into the country & faces 5 more. The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention says his detention ‚Äúis arbitrary.‚Äù http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_cJFXkAIYU3u.jpg

Buzurgmehr Yorov was sentenced by a Tajikistan court to 10+ years in prison for defending a client who claimed he was being tortured & framed. @amnesty wrote that the charges are ‚Äúlikely to be politically motivated.‚Äù He is at high #COVID19 risk due to prison conditions. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_Y84WoAE1jup.jpg

Journalist Daler Sharipov was detained in Tajikistan for ‚Äúinciting religious discord‚Äù for his work publishing articles on human rights and religious freedom. @HRW calls the charges ‚Äúfabricated‚Äù and ‚Äúbaseless.‚Äù He is at high #COVID19 risk due to prison conditions in Tajikistan. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_RXYXYAETH8B.jpg

Azimjon Askarov is serving a life sentence in Kyrgyzstan on trumped up charges. @UNHumanRights found he had been ‚Äúarbitrarily detained‚Ä¶tortured & mistreated, & prevented from adequately preparing his trial defence.‚Äù His health is deteriorating & he is at high #COVID19 risk. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_Iq5WAAE-XyH.jpg

Maks Bokayev was arrested in Kazakhstan for his work fighting for the environment, expression & against torture. The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention said his detention was based on his exercise of ‚Äúfreedom of expression & freedom of assembly.‚Äù He‚Äôs at high #COVID19 risk. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz_CgPXkAAfRj5.jpg

Aset Abishev was arrested in Kazakhstan for posts in support of Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan movement. @freedomhouse cited his case as an example of Kazakhstan persecuting opposition parties. He has been punished for expressing concerns about prison conditions & #COVID19. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ebz-2JlWoAIpifY.jpg

Individuals should never be imprisoned for peaceful activism. I urge Central Asian leaders to release prisoners held for these legitimate acts, including cases across #Kazakhstan, #Kyrgyzstan, #Tajikistan, #Turkmenistan & #Uzbekistan. The #COVID19 prison risk raises the stakes.

We all need health care at some point in our life. Access to quality affordable health care should be a right, not a privilege, and this vote takes us in that direction.

Over the last decade, Oklahoma's failure to expand Medicaid resulted in eight hospital closures and our state lost out on billions of dollars that should have gone to health care for our communities. Expanding Medicaid means a stronger investment in our health care system.

Medicaid expansion wins!! Oklahomans have voted to extend health care to working people in our state who for many years have fallen through the cracks. Medicaid expansion means that 200,000 more Oklahomans will now have access to the health care they need. This is a big victory.
